persona.name: Camila Fernanda Santillán Méndez

occupation.title: Community Cultural Coordinator / Program Manager
occupation.organization: Centro Cultural Barrio, a small non-profit cultural space (registered organization in CDMX)
occupation.description: Full-time program manager at a small cultural non-profit that produces weekly events (open-mic nights, local music showcases, artist residencies), runs weekend workshops (zine-making, basic sound engineering, dance), and mediates small municipal grants. She is formally employed with a modest salary and part-time social security benefits, but budgets are tight and contract renewals are annual.
responsibilities: Program planning: calendar of events, booking local acts, liaising with artists and instructors.
Community outreach: contact neighborhood groups, schools, and informal collectives to encourage participation.
Budgeting and basic accounting: manage petty cash, track ticket sales/box office, prepare expense reports for funders.
Grant writing and reporting: prepare short proposals for local cultural funds and write follow-up reports.
Marketing and communications: run the center's social media accounts, create posters, curate event pages and email lists.
Technical production: oversee soundchecks, coordinate volunteers and stagehands, sometimes run basic soundboard during events.
Partnerships: negotiate small sponsorships with local cafés or cooperatives for barter and in-kind support.
Volunteer management: train and schedule volunteers, manage interpersonal conflicts.
Monitoring and evaluation: collect attendance data, feedback forms, and document events (photos and short videos).
Safety & compliance: ensure events comply with local safety guidelines, handle basic first-aid incidents during busy nights.
skills_used_at_work: Digital communications and social media content creation
Simple audio/visual tech setup and troubleshooting
Negotiation for small partnerships and in-kind exchanges
occupation.working_hours_description: Typically 40–45 hours per week. Office hours run from 10:00–18:00 most weekdays; many evenings and weekends are spent at the venue for events. She often works some nights but has weekday mornings off occasionally. Contract is renewable annually and income fluctuates slightly with grant cycles.
main_challenges: Balancing creative ambitions with strict budget constraints.
Burnout risk from frequent evening and weekend work.
Low trust in municipal processes when applying for public funding.
Maintaining consistent attendance and volunteer engagement.
Ensuring fair pay for artists while keeping events affordable.

persona.education: Bachelor's degree in Communication and Cultural Management from Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM). Completed a final project on accessible community programming for independent music scenes in central Mexico. Active in student organizations, coordinated a small campus festival, completed internships at a municipal cultural center and at a small creative agency handling cultural events.
long_term_goals: Build and direct a small but stable cultural center that offers low-cost workshops, live-music nights, and exhibition space for local artists.
Create a cooperative that helps independent performers and artisans formalize their businesses and access benefits (social security, microloans).
Achieve enough financial stability to buy a modest ground-floor home in a central neighborhood where she can host cultural gatherings.
Travel through Latin America for extended periods (3-6 months) to research community arts practices and document stories for a digital archive.
Gain recognition in the national cultural scene as someone who opens real opportunities for emerging artists from working-class neighborhoods.
Learn advanced documentary filmmaking and release a short feature about female musicians from the central highlands.
Be able to support her parents in retirement without depending on them, and help her younger relatives with education costs.
Secure a professional certification in project management and grant writing to improve the center's sustainability.
Build a small, reliable emergency savings fund (6 months of living expenses) and a rudimentary retirement plan.
Keep growing a tight-knit community of creative people who collaborate across disciplines — music, visual arts, performance — and avoid burnout while doing it.
persona.style: Urban, approachable, and slightly theatrical when working — mixes Mexican colloquialisms with occasional English tech terms. Speaks with a Mexico City urban accent (chilango) but softens speech when talking to elders. Uses contemporary slang (e.g., "onda", "chido", "qué tal") but avoids overly aggressive phrasing. Tends to laugh softly after making a wry observation. Dresses eclectically: vintage band tees paired with second-hand blazers, high-waisted jeans, chunky boots, and colorful enamel pins supporting social causes. Wears minimal makeup, prefers clear nail polish, and often has hair tied back in a loose bun when at events. Gestures with her hands a lot when excited; uses her phone constantly, often narrating short videos out loud as she shoots them. Polite and friendly in introductions, but direct about expectations and deadlines. In written communication she uses short, warm paragraphs, emojis in informal messages (heart, clapping hands), and clear bullet points for logistical emails. Very active on Instagram and Twitter/X for work, posts on TikTok for creative promotion, and uses WhatsApp extensively for rapid coordination. When nervous she chews the inside of her cheek and fiddles with a ring on her right hand. Refers to people by nicknames in casual conversation (e.g., "Lalo", "Fede"). Comfortable speaking in front of crowds but occasionally mumbles when tired.

traits: Curious — seeks new experiences, music scenes, and ideas from different neighborhoods.
Sociable — energized by small gatherings, open-mic nights, and community meetings.
Empathetic — attentive to artists' needs and sensitive to volunteers' burnout.
Pragmatic — makes cost-effective decisions under constraints; values realistic solutions.
Idealistic — believes art can change lives and strengthen community ties.
Restless — gets bored with repetitive administrative tasks and looks for creative outlets.
Perseverant — keeps projects alive despite delays and bureaucratic hurdles.
Impatient with hypocrisy — calls out performative activism politely but firmly.
Self-critical — worries about doing things "right" and can replay mistakes mentally.
Playful — has a quick, sometimes sarcastic sense of humor with friends.

big_five.openness: Very high (9/10). Loves new experiences, art, travel, and unconventional ideas.
big_five.conscientiousness: Moderate (6/10). Generally organized for events but can be flexible and defer small details.
big_five.extraversion: High (8/10). Feels energized by social contact and public events; enjoys networking.
big_five.agreeableness: Moderate-high (7/10). Cooperative and compassionate but willing to set firm boundaries.
big_five.neuroticism: Moderate (5/10). Experiences occasional anxiety and self-doubt but manages stress through social support and small routines.

interests: Independent and regional Mexican music scenes (rock en español, indie, cumbia electrónica).
Live music and small venue culture — enjoys discovering new bands at DIY shows.
Street food and neighborhood eateries (tacos al pastor, quesadillas de hoja, tortas).
Documentary photography and short-form audiovisual storytelling.
Zine culture, collage, and low-cost printmaking.
Local festivals and patron saint celebrations reimagined with modern programming.
Streetwear mixed with vintage fashion — shopping at mercados de pulgas and thrift shops.
Sustainable living practices within the city: bike commuting, refill stores, thrift swaps.
Social media as a tool for community organization (Instagram storytelling, event promotion).
Participatory workshops: leading zine-making, basic sound-tech for beginners, and songwriting sessions.
Podcasts about culture, feminism, urbanism, and music scenes.
Traveling domestically — weekend trips to Puebla, Oaxaca, and Valle de Bravo for inspiration.
Graphic design basics; enjoys creating posters and flyers with bold typography.
Attending panels on cultural policy and municipal funding.
Volunteer-run collectives and cooperatives supporting artisans.
Learning practical skills: basic plumbing fixes in her rented apartment, simple sewing.
Salsa and cumbia dancing socially; attends occasional dance nights to unwind.
Curating small exhibitions that center marginalized voices.
Exploring new cafes for remote work: likes indie cafes over chains.
Supporting feminist and LGBTQ+ cultural events.
likes: Strong, slightly sweet coffee (café de olla sometimes) in small independent cafés with good Wi-Fi.
Listening to mixtapes and playlists she made for specific moods or events.
Late-afternoon golden light in the venue's rehearsal room — perfect for photos.
Affordable design stores and second-hand clothing stalls.
Street murals and public art that reference local histories.
Collaborative playlists for events, where each artist adds a track.
Hosting potlucks with friends after shows — everyone brings a dish.
Simple, honest conversations about money and sustainability among creatives.
Portable speakers and small analog synths for pop-up performances.
Using Google Forms for quick feedback after events.
Public transportation over taxis when possible — prefers to take the Metrobús or metro for shorter trips.
Putting small handwritten notes into grant applications to show local impact.
Summer radio nights featuring community-curated tracks.
A clean, well-labeled supply closet at the center — hates chaos during load-ins.
A playlist of Chilean indie and Mexican alternative during work hours.
Clear communications and brief, respectful meeting agendas.
A reliable local printer for posters and zines.
When older neighbors compliment the center's family days.
Receiving gratitude from participants who learned a new skill at a workshop.
Strong fluorescent pens for quick poster mockups.
Late-night tacos after a gig — a tradition with her friends.
Being invited to bring the center to a small municipal cultural fair.
Discounted artist fees negotiated in good faith.
Finding a reasonably priced venue for an experimental performance.
Watching small artists she booked go on to larger stages.
dislikes: Performative social media activism that does not result in tangible support.
Bureaucratic delays that stall grant decisions for months without explanation.
Big venues that displace local communities under the guise of cultural development.
People who speak over others in meetings (dominant personalities).
High service fees on ticket platforms that eat into artists' pay.
Unclear communication from partners and sponsors about deliverables.
When volunteers cancel at the last minute for important events.
Overpriced artisan markets that exploit makers instead of paying them fairly.
Closed-minded criticism that rejects experimentation outright.
Being pigeonholed as a "female organizer" rather than a program manager.
Public officials who treat culture as a checkbox rather than an investment.
Inauthentic branding from organizations that co-opt community aesthetics.
Gentrification-driven closures of beloved street vendors and community spaces.
Indifference to accessibility needs (no ramps, no seats for elders).
Poorly mixed sound at small shows — too much bass, unintelligible vocals.
Lack of clear agreements with artists about recording and streaming rights.
Being interrupted during presentations or workshops.
Pay-to-play models that exclude low-income artists.
Platforms that change algorithms without transparent rationale.
Being gaslit about budgets or previous agreements.
People who assume she is an unpaid volunteer despite having a formal position.
Slow email replies from partners when coordination is urgent.
Toxic work cultures that romanticize overwork in the arts.
Cafés that claim to be "art-friendly" but forbid events without permission.
Artists being underpaid or asked to provide unpaid PR in exchange for 'exposure'.
When municipal funds are redirected without community consultation.

beliefs: Culture and arts are essential public goods that should be publicly supported, not only commodified.
Government should play an active role in funding health and education for everyone.
Public healthcare access is a right and should be strengthened (supports universal/expanded healthcare).
Corruption in municipal and national institutions is a major barrier to social programs.
Redistribution and social programs are necessary to reduce inequality and create opportunities.
Small cultural centers provide social cohesion and reduce youth marginalization.
Artists should be paid fairly for their work, even in grassroots spaces.
Gig and informal work needs pathways to formalization with social protections.
Progressive policies (education, healthcare, housing) improve quality of life more than tax cuts.
Support for Morena is often pragmatic — values social programs but remains critical of specific officials.
Trust in government institutions is low; transparency and accountability measures are needed.
Local parties and collectives can sometimes be more effective than distant national structures.
Cultural policy should be co-designed with community stakeholders, not top-down.
Indigenous and regional cultural practices deserve respect, protection, and appropriate compensation.
Women's rights and LGBTQ+ rights are non-negotiable; culture must reflect diverse voices.
Public spaces should belong to residents, not to private developers.
Tourism should be managed so it benefits local communities and does not commodify traditions.
Education must include practical skills (financial literacy, basic tech) for creatives.
Mental health is a public health issue and needs greater public funding and de-stigmatization.
Climate change mitigation should be part of municipal planning (urban greenery, active transport).
Small businesses and cooperatives deserve microcredit and technical assistance to survive.
Community-led safety initiatives can complement public policing when done with accountability.
Police reform is necessary; communities need alternatives that focus on prevention.
Digital platforms are powerful for outreach but can exploit creators through opaque policies.
Privacy online matters — people should be informed and in control of how their content is used.
Artists should collaborate rather than compete; solidarity raises overall visibility for scenes.
Access to affordable internet is crucial for cultural participation and work opportunities.
Public funding cycles are unpredictable; multi-year funding would allow for real planning.
Family obligations are important but should not be a reason to undervalue one's professional time.
Religion can be cultural and personal, but institutions should not dictate public policy.
Migration is complex; migration from smaller towns to the city often reflects regional inequality.
Young people's activism is often more pragmatic than ideological — they demand solutions.
Personal savings are important but public safety nets reduce the need for precarious financial choices.
Informal solutions (barter, in-kind exchanges) are creative stopgaps but should not replace formal labor rights.
Cultural appropriation is a real concern; credit and compensation are needed when traditions are reused.
Local languages and dialects should be visible in public programming and signage.
Art education in schools should be preserved and expanded, especially in low-income districts.
There is hope — change takes time and small projects can accumulate into structural shifts.
Community narratives are powerful; documenting local stories resists forgetting and marginalization.
skills: Event planning and logistics (scheduling, artist contracting, load-in/load-out coordination).
Basic bookkeeping, expense tracking, and preparing financial reports for small organizations.
Grant writing and preparing concise reports for municipal cultural funds and private sponsors.
Social media management (Instagram, Twitter/X, Facebook) with content strategies tailored to small audiences.
Content creation: photography (mobile and DSLR basics), short-form video editing (basic Premiere/CapCut), and Instagram reels.
Basic audio setup: microphone placement, simple soundcheck, running a small digital mixer for live shows.
Graphic layout for posters and zines using Canva and basic Adobe Illustrator skills.
Volunteer recruitment, training, and conflict mediation.
Public speaking and MC-ing — hosts events and introductions smoothly.
Basic HTML/CSS knowledge for maintaining a small WordPress site or event pages.
Negotiation for sponsorships and in-kind support with local businesses.
Community outreach — building relationships with schools, neighborhood associations, and collectives.
Short-form documentary interviewing and oral history recording techniques.
Project budgeting and forecasting for one-year cycles.
Self-taught zine production: layout, printing, and distribution strategies.
Spanish (native), English (conversational; RSL intermediate), some understanding of regional indigenous phrases used in nearby areas.
Time management under irregular hours and shifting priorities.
Problem-solving in high-pressure live event situations (e.g., last-minute cancellations).
Basic first-aid and crowd management for small events.
Teaching and workshop facilitation for beginners in arts and tech.

general: Often uses WhatsApp groups to coordinate volunteers and artists; keeps several groups with layered permissions.
Posts short 'behind-the-scenes' stories on Instagram during events to document and promote the center.
Saves receipts scrupulously and photographs them for expense reports at the end of each week.
Checks municipal cultural funding websites monthly and flags new opportunities to the team.
Organizes quick post-event debriefs with volunteers (10–15 minutes) to collect feedback.
Takes public transport most days but will take a taxi late at night after events for safety.
Regularly recommends local artists to friends and external curators to help them grow networks.
Likes to split the tab on group dinners fairly, but occasionally covers a friend's meal when finances allow.
Avoids long meetings without clear agendas; suggests concise objectives and action points.
Uses playlists to set moods for different tasks (e.g., instrumental lo-fi while doing admin).

morning: Wakes around 8:30 AM on weekdays, checks phone for messages and ticket sales from the previous night.
Makes coffee (often from beans bought at a local roaster) and eats a quick breakfast — fruit and yogurt or a tamal when in a rush.
Skims emails and updates a shared calendar before leaving for the office around 9:45–10:00 AM.
Takes the metro or Metrobús with earbuds in, listening to a podcast about culture or policy.
workday: Arrives at the center around 10:30 AM, checks the venue, and confirms volunteer attendance.
Morning: administrative tasks — invoices, emails, grant drafts, scheduling.
Afternoon: meetings with artists, suppliers, or partner cafés; troubleshooting logistics.
Late afternoon: social media posts, preparing materials for evening workshops or shows.
Evenings: supervises soundcheck, greets artists and guests, MCs event segments, handles ticketing and admissions.
evening: After events, spends 20–40 minutes checking in with volunteers and cleaning shared spaces.
Often eats late-night tacos with friends or a quick torta before going home.
Spends 30–60 minutes editing a short clip or selecting photos to post the next day.
Calls or messages her mother to check in before bed if possible.
Sleeps between midnight and 2:00 AM after a busy night; tries to wind down with a short podcast.
weekend: Saturday mornings: coordinates smaller community workshops or pop-up markets.
Afternoons: sometimes DJs a small set at a friend's event or attends a cultural panel.
Sunday: a slower day — launders, reviews next week's calendar, and has a long dinner with roommates or family.
Occasional weekend trips to visit family in Estado de México or to scout venues in Puebla or Oaxaca.

health.general_health: Good overall. Active lifestyle — walks and cycles around the neighborhood, uses stairs when possible.
physical_conditions: Mild adult-onset acne that flares with stress.
Near-sighted (uses prescription glasses and sometimes contact lenses).
Occasional seasonal allergies (pollen), takes antihistamines as needed.
No chronic diseases; up-to-date on routine vaccinations including COVID boosters.
mental_health: Occasional anxiety during high-pressure grant cycles and event weekends.
Has attended group therapy/peer support workshops in the past year and finds them helpful.
Uses breathing exercises and short walks to manage acute stress.
Worries about burnout and actively tries to set boundaries (e.g., one day each week with no work messages).
health.healthcare_access: Uses a mix of public healthcare (IMSS or municipal clinics for routine care) and occasional private services when affordable. Supports strengthening public healthcare and prefers it to be more reliable.
lifestyle: Mostly balanced diet but often eats street food late after events.
Exercises irregularly — keeps active through work and biking rather than formal gym routines.
Sleeps inconsistently around busy event schedules; tries to catch up on rest during quieter weeks.
medical_history: Minor dental cavities treated in early adulthood; tries to keep up with dental hygiene.
Regular gynecological check-ups and uses a hormonal contraceptive method (pill) with periodic monitoring.

relationships.name: Mariana Santillán (mother)
relationships.relationship: Mother; works as an administrative clerk in a municipal office. Close relationship, frequent phone calls, mutual emotional support. Lives in Estado de México; Camila sends small sums when possible and visits monthly.

relationships.name: Héctor Santillán (father)
relationships.relationship: Father; ran a small hardware store for many years, semi-retired. Pragmatic and supportive, occasionally gives practical advice about budgeting and small repairs.

relationships.name: Lucas Santillán (younger brother)
relationships.relationship: Younger brother studying engineering in a nearby university. Close, teases each other often, Camila helps him with resumes and invites him to events to expose him to cultural scenes.

relationships.name: Housemates: Paula and Neto
relationships.relationship: Two roommates from the cultural scene — share rent, chores, and post-event meals. Good chemistry, share creative critique and occasional late-night planning sessions.

relationships.name: Close circle of friends (approx. 6 people)
relationships.relationship: Friends from university and the music scene: Lalo (sound tech), Fernanda (visual artist), Diego (promoter), Sofía (graphic designer), Ana (teacher), and Camilo (musician). Regular socializing, mutual favors, and artistic collaborations.

relationships.name: Mentor: Teresa
relationships.relationship: Former professor at UNAM who advised her thesis and now provides advice on grant writing and professional opportunities. Meets quarterly or when specific projects require feedback.

relationships.name: Romantic life
relationships.relationship: Single, open to relationships but prioritizes career stability; occasional casual dating, values partners who respect her time and creative work. Prefers partners who are politically aware and supportive of community work.

relationships.name: Professional network
relationships.relationship: Large informal network across CDMX: venue owners, municipal cultural officers, local artists, small-business owners. Uses this network to find artists, suppliers, and cross-promotional partners.

other_facts: Grew up in a mixed neighborhood in the Estado de México and moved to Mexico City at 18 to study at UNAM.
Her grandmother taught her to cook mole and other family recipes; she still makes mole for special dinners with friends.
Has a small tattoo of a vinyl record on her inner forearm, done during a night out after a festival — symbolic of her love for music.
Owns a second-hand 35mm film camera she uses for portraits of artists; developed her first roll at a community darkroom workshop.
Was pickpocketed once on a crowded metro during a festival, an experience that changed how she carries valuables and increased her focus on safety planning for events.
Speaks Spanish natively and studied English through university courses and online platforms; uses English for reading some music journalism and grant materials.
Has around 4,000 combined followers across Instagram and Twitter/X — an engaged audience for local cultural events but not influencer-level reach.
Once organized a pop-up event in a small café that helped one local band get noticed by a regional promoter — a major professional win she is proud of.
Is frugal about personal purchases: prefers to invest in tools for work (audio equipment, reliable headphones) over fast fashion.
Loves the smell of rain on hot pavement (petrichor) and associates it with creative energy.
Collects old concert flyers and has a small wall collage in her room documenting friends' shows over the past five years.
Has a short, recurring debt from her student loan cohort that she pays monthly; uses a small portion of each paycheck to chip away at it.
Saves small amounts regularly in a joint savings goal app with one of her roommates for an annual travel fund.
Once attended a three-week cultural residency in Oaxaca where she learned traditional weaving techniques and made lasting friendships with artisans.
Participated in a municipal youth council during university that sparked her interest in cultural policy.
Has a rescue cat named Frida who lives with her parents; misses the cat but visits on weekends.
Is allergic to some common perfumes and avoids strong-scented spaces when planning events for people with sensitivities.
Kept a journal through her teens and early twenties — many entries include lists of bands, zine ideas, and notes on community mapping.
Prefers paper notebooks for brainstorming, then digitizes selected notes into a Trello board for project management.
Has a small collection of enamel pins from events and causes she supports; wears them on a jacket used while traveling to shows.
Once had a project rejected by a funder in a dismissive email; she saved that email as motivation to improve grant-writing clarity and persistence.
Believes in ritualizing small transitions — e.g., a 10-minute walk after an event to decompress and mentally close the night.
Enjoys teaching and has led workshops for teenagers in under-resourced neighborhoods, which she finds deeply rewarding.
Is cautious about building her credit score and has a modest credit card used for business expenses, paid monthly to avoid interest.
Keeps an emergency kit in the venue with band-aids, earplugs, a flashlight, and basic tools because she learned the hard way during a blackout.
Has a recurring monthly meet-up called 'Domingos de Zines' where local artists trade zines and community stories.
Was a volunteer at a student-led radio show that shaped her interest in community media and storytelling.
Keeps a spreadsheet of local suppliers (printers, sound techs, catering) with notes on price, reliability, and past experiences.
Enjoys learning short phrases in indigenous languages she encounters at markets and often includes them in event signage when invited by elders.
Is ambidextrous in casual tasks (writes right-handed but sometimes uses her left for small gestures).
Once collaborated on a short radio documentary that aired on a local community station about youth culture in her neighborhood.
Has experienced microaggressions in professional settings but uses them as occasions to set boundaries and educate peers when appropriate.
Belongs to an informal mutual-aid group that rotates responsibility for caring for members during illnesses or emergencies.
Maintains a small collection of USB drives with copies of event photos, contracts, and templates for invoices and posters.
Enjoys mentoring one or two younger volunteers each year and tracking their progress; takes pride in seeing them grow into paid roles.
Has a superstition of always checking venue exits before leaving, born from concern about safety after a crowded show left people stranded.
Was once offered a higher-paying but soul-draining job at a corporate events firm and turned it down because it conflicted with her values.
Keeps a mental inventory of local artists who would pair well for surprise lineups; has become known for tight, well-curated bills.
Uses a ring of rubber bands around her wrist as a tactile reminder list — each band corresponds to a task; when a task is done she removes the band.
Enjoys the quiet hours after an event when the staff sits together drinking instant coffee and swapping arbitrary stories — considers these moments restorative.
Has been learning basic accounting skills through online courses to professionalize the center's finances and reduce reliance on outside consultants.
Often recommends local cultural spaces to newcomers in the city as a way of building stronger networks and mutual support.
